reviewText:
I have always enjoyed the first two Final Fantasy games, but their stories were sparse, relying more on conversations with random town folk to help fill in the blanks than to tell a proper tale. While Final Fantasy III still shows its age and might not have the sophistication found in later RPGs, it is still a worthy look back at a game that helped to continue to redefine the genre.

This version of the game on PC is based on the graphically updated version that made its way onto the Nintendo DS back in 2006. The visuals got an 3D overhaul, with a widened aspect ratio and some new features as well. If you are familiar with the DS or iPhone/iPad versions of the game this PC release will feel very familiar, but it still plays out nicely on a bigger screen.

Themes that persist and remain familiar in future Final Fantasy games such as the Warriors of Light and job class systems help populate this story. The job system is bare bones compared to what we are used to now in the series (and other games that use similar systems), and the game uses it more as a second experience system. On the one hand the characters have conventional experience systems that level up their physical attributes, and then there's the job levels which represent their skills. Managing both is easy, and the system does encourage players to jump their characters through multiple jobs, though there is some grinding involved as there is a warmup process where a character needs to fight a certain number of battles with a role before they're comfortable with it and can use its skills properly. You don't want to be fighting tough enemies in such a state, so you'll generally grind through easy battles each and every time you change classes.

This is a classic Final Fantasy title, which of course has both good and bad connotations. It means lots of menus and level grinding and of course chocobos and Cid and things. It is a welcome rush of nostalgia to come back to a game like this, which has aged well despite being nearly two and a half decades old. I'd be lying if I said that the graphical overhaul didn't make the game far more palatable (or the fact that the original game was never released in English), but the core mechanics should also appeal to old school JRPG fans. The game gets off to something of a slow start, with a lot of story and limited exploration during the first dozen hours or so, but once it opens up it is every bit the exploration-filled adventure Final Fantasy is known for, filled with little secrets to find and fun and diverse characters.

Having just played Bravely Default a few months ago and seeing familiar themes such as the four different adventurers brought together by circumstance and the presence of crystals as a focal point to the story, I could not help but be amused with how timeless the narrative themes are. That being said, Bravely Default showed just how much further game storytelling has gone in making something rich out of the basic thematic construct. That is not to say that Final Fantasy III has a poor story, but compared to the more modern Japanese role-playing game, it is fascinating to see how far the medium has come.

If you have already played the DS or iOS version of this game, there may not be enough of a reason to purchase it on Steam now. However, if you missed that opportunity before and want to experience an important part of Final Fantasy's early evolution, this is an excellent way to do so. The character depth and story detail might feel somewhat lacking compared to newer JRPG titles, but there is an expansive world here that begs for exploration as you grow your characters for future challenges. The overall package is an easy one to recommend.

Refreshed & challenging // Recommended for fans of the franchise
+ Inventory & spell system is rudimentary compared to modern RPG standards, but still manages to feel polished & well-implemented
+ Job system works well with combat, & offers that little extra bit of additional customization of play

+ Visuals & audio have had a satisfying overhaul
+ Agreeable length; one feels as though they are gatting their money's worth of the product in terms of time investment

- Characters have precious little depth or development (especially compared to most other installments of the series), & the often uninspired dialogue doesn't much help
- Plot is comparatively shallow, and diverges only slightly from the original product
- Destinations are often unclear; it's all too easy to get turned around & not know where the next town is located

reviewText:
Just to start off, if you're looking at this game as a potential gateway to getting into traditional JRPG's, don't bother.  It will only serve to put you off the genre all together.  There are just too many things, like lack of save points and some cheap bosses, for someone that may want to play a more old-school game and is looking at FFIII, the earliest available FF game on Steam, as the game to start out with.

That said, if you've played a lot of old RPG's growing up, you may find something more to your liking here.  The story and characters are simple.  There's no voice acting, no FMV cutscenes, no minimap or compass to point you in the right direction.  I found all of the above a benefit to the game.  The story parts would be slowed down by voice acting and the generic story would be exposed further if you had to listen to it and instead of just reading text.  While the game is fairly linear, it does a great job at points of making you wonder where to go and there's a real sense of exploration.  There's like five or more villages you don't ever have to go to for any reason that are just there, and despite them being pretty small, it's a cool little thing that you'd never see in a more modern game.

The big thing with this game is that in was the introduction of the job-swapping system found in the earlier FF's.  There are twenty plus jobs and they're handed out at set points in the story.  The big problem is the last set of jobs are unlocked extremely late in the game and this makes using them to their fullest a pain.  You can switch jobs on the fly but there's a small penalty to stats for x amount of fights.  It's not a big deal and will only hamper you for a handful of random battles.

The big downside to the game is complete lack of effort when redesigning the boss encounters and the final dungeon in its entirety.  Every boss fight boils down to the same thing.  A single enemy will have a strong physical attack that hits one character and strong magic attacks that hits everyone.  Bosses will also always use these attacks back to back without interruption.  This means any character, even with full HP, is liable to get KO'd if they get RNG unlucky when it comes to boss turns versus your characters' turns.  It's such a cheap, low-effort way to add difficulty when designing bosses.  Every turn of every boss fight eventually winds up with you casting a group heal spell on an already fully healed group just to deal with the oncoming attacks.

The last dungeon and it's surroundings is one of the worst in RPG's and I'm sure you can find detailed reasons why elsewhere.

There's a lot of talk about grinding being necessary in this game and I find that completely overblown.  I never stopped my progress for the explicit grinding of levels/ job levels and beat the game with levels in the very low 50's.  Grinding some levels would have helped for the last boss to serve as an HP buffer but it's not necessary.  As long as you don't continuously change your jobs, you should be able to handle anything the game can throw at you as long you fight every random encounter you come across.  The secret boss though would require a ton, and I mean a ton, of grinding and I didn't bother with it.

As for the port, it's a super low effort one of the mobile version, not the DS version.  This means stuff like the UI is ugly and created to be touch based, but lacking in touch suport or mouse control in menus in this version and is just poor all around.  Even things like loading your game while in-game is obtuse.  There are only three save slots for who knows what reason.  I also ran into a problem where all dialogue box text had some type of artifacting or something that I couldn't find a work around for.  All that said, it's still supposedly better the FFIV PC port, which doesn't even have the memorize battle cursor function because it wasn't included in the mobile version and has 15 FPS in battles.  I used the memorize function in FFIII so I'll be missing it when I eventually get around to playing FFIV.  Square just doesn't give a ♥♥♥♥ with any of their PC ports so none of this should be a surprise.

Okay, since this was really long, here's a short answer as to whether you should buy and play this game.  Don't if you have no experience with older RPG's.  If you do and are fine with not having things like save points and easily obtainable reviving items, cheap bosses and a terrible final dungeon, you'd probably get some enjoyment out of FFIII.  It's an enjoyable, but clearly flawed game.

The first bug I encountered: On leaving Castle Sasune I decided to go back to the starting village and see if I missed anything. When I talked to the Elder in town, the storyline restarted and I had to go back through gathering my party, whose levels had all reset to 3, 3, and 4, respectively, by going through all the cutscenes over again.

The Second bug I encountered: While on The Enterprise (Boat) I got into a battle, a lot of them, to try and level against the new monsters because YAAY DIVERSITY, only to come out of my 20th or so battle and realize I was standing in the ocean. There was no ship sprite, I was Luneth being followed by Desch.. standing on the ocean. The background music had stopped and I was unable to go back on land, and when I went past the first continent, the Big Rock that bars your passage before defeating Djinn was there again. Wee~ saved to an empty file and reloaded, bug not fixed.

The Third bug, and the funniest (in a cruel sort of way): After speaking with a friend about a treasure room just inside the crystal cave, I decided to head back there on The Enterprise (Save Often) and check it out, if only for the Achievement progress. I skipped the first village because I'd already dealt with that bug and I wasn't risking it. Go in to the cave, grab the loot and spot a hole in the floor. The last bug I found was upon restarting the game after the third bug: I loaded up my save and there I was in the middle fo the Ocean on The Enterprise. I decide to quickly get the hell off this boat before it glitches on me again. Got into a fight with 2 Hermits. Killed them quickly, was back on my boat, and two achievements popped up. Apparently I saved a lot of Gil, because I got both of the Gil-related achievements for nothing.


All in all, a great game but I have to play it in small chunks because of the ridiculous amount of bugs I've run into. Its frustrating, and I won't recommend the purchase of this game to any but the most stalwart of Final Fantasy fans.

reviewText:
Good remake of an old favorite.

Pros
- Job system is interesting with lots of options
- Decent amount of grind v. story.  Lots of opportunity to max everything though if that's your thing
- Bosses and new mobs can pose a threat
- Finishing a job gets you a legendary item for that class

Cons
- Some jobs are worthless
- Zero description of Job Points - had to read a guide
- Fastest way to level a job?  Just have all your guys Guard 7 times for an automatic job level at the end of the fight.  Should have been based on job special skills - Knights using Defend, Thief using Steal, mages using magic for the biggest boost, medium boost for normal actions like attacking, and very little for using items (unless Scholar) or Guarding.  I've maxed out a lot of the FF games and couldn't force myself to do it here.
- Low agility characters/jobs end up at a disadvantage if you don't use the Guard method of job leveling.  They don't get to take an action and thus level slower than everyone else.
- Legendary smith - difficult to access without looking at a guide, pops up in random places causing you to fly between two cities until she shows up at just to get your new job weapon, etc.  Poorly conceived.
- Nothing carries over when you switch jobs.  It would be nice to keep some residual stats - Knight to White Mage should keep a little defense or vitality.
- Save issue during the last boss.  Fight through a dungeon, fight boss, no save option except for quick save (does not allow you to resume there if you die).  Can't teleport or travel back to world map for a full save.  Enter final dungeon - if you happen to approach the final boss first like I did, you're screwed and you get one shotted meaning you lose about 20 minutes of progress and have to watch some really long cutsceens again.

All in all, glad I picked it up on sale and got to see what they did with the remake.

FF3 is a decent fantasy rpg that features a short and straightforward plotline. It boasts numerous job choices and combinations similar to its NES counterpart and the tactics series.

This game is of course not without drawbacks. Among other titles in the FF series, I would rank this as slightly  above average due to one or two missing (but important) features.

The game does not have an option to adjust battle speed. This was something you could find in FF games of previous generations so it's a shame that this isn't built into the PC port of the game. Keep in mind that there's an achievement for getting all jobs to level 99 which will require a minimum of 2254 battles (that's if you're super efficient) so this particular option would have been a godsend.

Content-wise, I also feel that it is below/lacking in comparison to the 2 other games which are also on Steam. This is purely subjective but I feel that the price point needs to be adjusted after considering this factor. It's a shame because the game ends before it truly begins. You get your last set of jobs way too close to the end of the game.

Despite these criticisms, I can still recommend FF3. It follows a nostalgic formula that most of the other games in the series observe. The game is especially good if you are a modern gamer who missed out on the treasured experience of playing the first half of the series.

reviewText:
Pure, unspoiled Final Fantasy at its best.
I first played this game back in 2006 when it was introduced stateside to the Nintendo DS and I loved every freaking minute of it. Final Fantasy III is a sweet, charming, and satisfying Final Fantasy experience. The style of the music, the artwork, and the feel of the game has yet to be replicated.

Luneth, Arc, Inguis, and Refia are four adventurers who become the Warriors of Light. Their roles in the party are based on which jobs you assign to them that unlock as you progress through the story. The story is simple but engaging enough to want to see through to the end.

This game is HARD, especially when you're used to the more modern FF titles. I can't sugarcoat the difficulty at all. You will rarely get a phoenix down, so trips back to town to revive fallen party members may happen frequently. If you are looking for a challenge, you will certainly find it here.

It's kinda sad that it took over a decade for this gem to see a US release, but it has already taken place as one of my favorite games of all time and one of my favorite FF titles. Completing this game is one of the most rewarding experiences ever. I recommend getting both FF3 and FF4 on Steam as both are challenging in their own ways but offer different experiences.

reviewText:
After playing the Famicom version of this game, I was hesitant to give this remake a try.  I have to say I was pleasantly surprised at how much of an improvement this game made over the original.  Rather than make an essay about the changes, I'll go point-by-point.

+ Better graphics, obviously.  Granted, the Famicom version looked marvelous in the 8-bit era, but since this is a PC-optimized port of the DS game, I'm glad to see some 3D graphics in there.

+ Better story.  The plot was a lot looser in the original, and the characters had no backstory at all.  By assigning default names to each character and expanding on their origins, the plot feels more cohesive and I connect with the characters better.

+ Better use of the job system.  It's still not as crisp as Final Fantasy V, but the major gripe I had playing the Famicom version is that many job types became obsolete very quickly.  Some were never useful from the start, and the Scholar job was only necessary for one boss fight.  This remake changed all of that.  More jobs are useful for longer periods of time, and even in the late-game stages you can downgrade to a lesser job and still function well.

+ Better difficulty curve.  The original game was HARD.  Frankly, without a strategy guide, beating that game would have been near impossible.  But the remake softens the blow a lot and makes the game much more enjoyable.  You never feel like you're bringing the game to a screeching halt so that you can grind job levels or character levels.  It flows much more smoothly.

Overall, this game was in dire need of a remake, and this one does the job quite well.  If you've never played Final Fantasy III, or if the Famicom version left a bad taste in your mouth, then I strongly recommend picking this up.  You'll be glad you did.

While it is a port of the DS remake, it has enough of the simplicity and that grindy flavor to hit the spot for that early Final Fantasy JRPG nostalgia (note: I've experienced no issues with the port).

Much of this is owed to the fact that this game is almost a verbatim remake, which reflects the restrictions of the ancient technology of 1990, when the game was first released. The redsign of the game was primarily only a visual & audio makeover (updated music, '3D' environments & sprites, etc). The gameplay and construction are almost identical to the original.

This means that there really isn't much at all to the story, and the characters are pretty much completely flat. So if you're expecting the rich development you'd find in the story and characters of the later installments in the series (pretty much any of them after this one), look elsewhere.

Further, the maps used in the original games have been retained here - and that includes the limitations in design, as  So, similar to the limited story, dialogue, and characters, you'll find that they're disappointingly simple.

While all the above might seem like a pile of complaints, it's actually not. What has been redone, has been redone well. The visuals are limited to that of a DS, however im finding that the music is really enjoyable. All in all, it's been a fun experience - just don't expect this to compare to the modern (high-budget) maserpieces that the Series produces.

Bottom line: if you're looking for a nostalgic feel with a bit of modern flavor, this just might hit the spot.

I am fully aware that this is a port of the DS version, but it is still great to play some of the older games in this new console generation, as the current generation of FF games have not lived up to their expectations. Except A Realm Reborn. Damn that was good.

Final Fantasy III was the only FF game that was not released in NA or Europe until the 2006 DS remake, and like said above this is esentially the same game. It was also the first FF game to introduce the Jobs system, a mechanic which allows you to choose and switch between different classes in-game, a system that has been used in many Final Fantasy games in the following years.

Final Fantasy III is pretty much your standard Final Fantasy game. Magic chrystal, mystical bossfights, cliché characters and damn hard boss fights. I can see any fan of the series enjoying this game, but it's not something for new comers. If you want to get yourself into the FF universe, start off with FF VII - which is widely regarded as the best Final Fantasy game (not in my opinion, but hey)

All in all, as a fan of the series I can say I have enjoyed the DS version and this PC port. I reccommend it to fans of the francise too.

reviewText:
This sure is Final Fantasy 3,

firstly i want to talk about the port, this is a bare bones cheap and nasty port from the mobile version straight to the PC, no bells, no whistles, and considering that the android and iOS version is itself a port from the DS remake what we have here is some butt ugly textures and models being displayed at a high resolution that does them no courtesy, the sound is straight from the DS is is everything else, the game doesnt even fit to the proper aspect ratio, be prepared for 2 black bars to run vertically down the sides of your screen, there are barely any options to toggle this game has trading cards and controller support and that is literally about it, not enough to justify the price for anyone familiar with FF3

The first three Final Fantasy games are very easy to group together, they are easilly the worst the franchise (with the exception of 13 and its iterations) but they are still important games that made mistakes that would only surface themselves through time.

3 has a class system in place that anyone familiar with 5 or 14 should feel comfortable with, you can select Jobs and level them individually as well as level your own characters base stats. 5 handles this better but this is the first FF game to bring in the system,

personally id argue 3's biggest flaws are the same as FF1 and FF2's flaws but on a larger scale, Heavy grinding, vague story and a large overworld easy to get lost in, this to some people sounds like hell while to others it probably sounds great, this is an NES era RPG and this port doesnt do much to change that for better or for worse.

its still a cracking game albeit one i feel that has aged the least well, with a very large difficulty curve (that frog tower...oh my god) that is showing its age. If your already familiar with FF3 and merely looking to see what this PC port brings to the table, i cant recommend that the price is worth your time, equally if your looking for a decent JRPG on the PC, the poor port quality and how harsh and aged this game really is means that i cant recommend this over say child of light or Recettear.

However if you are intruiged to see what FF3 brings to the table on its own, and dont have access to the mobile ports (which could likely be found cheaper for the exact same content) and the sounds of a tough as nails old school JRPG sound good to you, then id recommend jumping in, maybe during a sale, theres just no reason this game should cost this much, 50% off though and id say go for it,

Note: This is just a problem with the Steam port of this game.

Although the experience is almost identical to the experience that you would receive playing this on iOS, there's a major problem with this port that iOS doesn't have. No matter where you are in the game, your story progress can be ultimately reset back to the starting town, Ur. You'll have to go through the whole story once again with three of the four characters going back to level 3/4. (Un)Fortunately, Luneth keeps his level, you keep all your items/spells, and all characters keep their job levels and current jobs.

If you still wish to buy this game, or have already bought it and are reading reviews after buying a game, just be sure to save frequently, but save carefully. If at any time you notice that your job icon is unavailable, fall back to your last save. If the job icon can't be chosen, it means that your game has been set back to the beginning of the storyline.

If you have a Nintendo DS or iOS device, or even a NES, I'd just recommend you buy it for that hardware to avoid this flaw.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy III was initially a mystery to gamers outside of Japan, having only been released on the Famicom in 1990. Since then, Final Fantasy III has been re-released several times; Nintendo DS, Playstation Portable, Wii’s Virtual Console, iOS, Android, and most recently making its way here to Steam. The game’s format and mechanics may feel a bit dated/unusual to those familiar with newer Final Fantasy titles, but I believe that the game still provides a worthwhile playing experience.

My first exposure to this game was the Nintendo DS version, which I picked up used for quite a bargain. That version is a 3D remake of the original Famicom game, and it appears that this PC version stayed loyal to that style. Due to the limited specifications on the Nintendo DS, I always felt that the game was a bit held back in the graphics and sound department. This PC version seems to have given the artwork better treatment, and appears to resemble the PSP version of the game more closely. I was concerned that the graphics would be overly pixelated due to the small resolution on handhelds, but was pleasantly surprised to see that the graphics felt right for PC.

The music, as usual in Final Fantasy titles, is superb. As a remake, they stayed very true to the themes present on the Famicom release. Many of the musical themes fit the mood of the game quite well, allowing the player to enjoy a calm stroll through a town or a hectic boss battle at the end of a dungeon. The sound quality is superb, as well, and doesn’t have the muffled sounds that the DS version provided.

Final Fantasy III’s combat system strays far from the system of its predecessor, and attempts to advance the system that was originally present in the original Final Fantasy. The player has the option to choose from a variety of jobs. As the player advances through the game and completes various quest “checkpoints” (for lack of a better word), additional jobs open up. Some of these jobs which offer a brand new range of healing, magic and utility, while some are simply upgrades to existing jobs. There are over two dozen jobs in total, giving players many chances to experiment. Along with jobs, this is the first Final Fantasy game to introduce summons. So if you’re familiar with summons in later titles such as Shiva and Bahamut, you’ll be right at home.

An immersing story has been an important part of the Final Fantasy franchise in recent years. Going back in time, however, it wasn’t always this way. In Final Fantasy III, the story is notably flat compared to the extended stories present in modern RPG titles. It’s easy to understand, rarely sees plot twists, and has a relatively small cast of characters. It’s nothing spectacular, but it was a step ahead from the two previous entries in the series. Unlike the Famicom Final Fantasy III, however, the characters in this version are given formal names. Despite the limited storytelling, I still feel it’s pleasant; just don't go in expecting a 50 hour long legendary tale.

The difficulty of this game is a bit jarring. The early game starts off quite bearable, giving players the ability to simply auto attack their way through many of the fiends. As the game progresses, the difficulty spikes up considerably. The final dungeons are notoriously difficult due to lack of save points and insufficient materials provided throughout the game. Compared to the difficulty of some modern Final Fantasy titles, the harsh difficulty in this game might turn some people away. But if you can fight through the barrage of random encounters and somehow make it through the dungeon, you’ll be rewarded with quite a sense of accomplishment.

In conclusion, I feel that Final Fantasy III is a worthy purchase for those who wish to revisit the roots of the Final Fantasy franchise, and JRPGs in general. It’s difficult, but rewarding. A worthy game for the name “Final Fantasy.”

I started playing final fantasy games about 10 years ago. I started with final fantasy X and was hooked shortly after. The series is amazing but I never went back to play anything below FFX. I heard the hype behind FFVII but I never like to buy into hype because it only serves to disappoint me usually. That being said, the very early final fantasys had sprites and I was not too interested in the low detail so I stayed on the other side of FFX.

Now, I saw this on sale at the Humble Store and I figured it would be a good time to try the older Final Fantasy games, given the polish this game had recieved.

It has a piece of gaming that I had missed with all the new games in the world now. It makes you want to play just because you want to discover new things. Not for the sake of driving the plot forward or saving X amount of people. It lets you do what you want and I get legitimately excited when I open a chest or find a new hidden area. It makes me feel like when I first started to play video games all so long ago and I haven't had this feeling since Valkyrie Profile:Leneth for the PSP. I actually want to grind and level my party up so I can kill monster and gain treasure. Almost a feeling akin to Skyrim but less open.

I guess it plays to the basic nature that players want to get treasure and go adventuring. Not for someone else but to see a new world, take a break from reality, of only for a moment. This game gives me a feeling I sought for a while and makes me like to play with the jobs and test out different party combinations.

Now, the game still has a linear story with areas opening up as you progress the role you are destined" to fulfill but the game doesn't push that on you too hard. You know that you have to save the world or some such thing but it isn't the reason you are playing. Or at least why I am playing. It doesn't seem to be wanting to center itself around the plot. It seems to want to center itself around you doing what you wish the areas open to you leading up to the plot driven boss battle so you can continut the quest.

In conclusion
date: it gives you the illusion of freedom even though it blocks you off at some points. The exploring of new caves and little hidden sparkles is fun. 10/10 would review again :D"

+ Job System (The job system is a definent pro of this game, you can take on any job any time you want, as long as you have access to it. However you do need to make tactical choices for which character, you gonna lean more on magic, cause when switched you have to begin again)
+ Music (The music is one of the plusses of the game, great masterpieces that remind you that you are really playing a JRPG)
+ Hope for more to come (Though this might not be linked to the game, it is a pro. Seeing that they did port this game to the PC, who knows what is more to come. The library is still extensive)

Maybe's:
* Graphics (I personally am very charmed by the graphics. I like this kind of art-style. It's also why I liked a lot of the RPG's on the DS. Plus the fact that they are indeed more detailed then on the DS. But however I can understand that some people are turned of by it. Take a cllose look to the screenshots, cause this is what you gonna get)
* Story (The story is a standard RPG-one. World is in peril and you have to save it. It doesn't have any super crazy plot twists or points, but it's more fleshed out then the orginal NES-story.)
* Difficulty (The game has a definent steep difficulty curve at some points in the game. Sometimes you can cruise right through a dungeon, only to find out in the next one you are major underleveled. This however is easier then the orginal game. They had also a bit more severe penalties on job-switching. It is a challenge. But if you are up for it. You gonna enjoy this)

Con's
- None (Personally I don't think this game has any con's really. A few maybe's yes. But it doesn't need you to sign in to Square-Enix as Final Fantasy VII and Final Fantasy VIII did. It's a real loveletter to the old classic Final Fantasy's. So yeah, it's a good game)

reviewText:
So, first ever Steam review so please be nice!

As a long time FF fan, I picked FF3 up as a historical curiosity more than anything, and frankly, that's the only reason to play it.  Time hasn't been kind to it, and it remains a fairly trite roll through JPRG cliches of the last 20 years.

That's not to say it's without merit.  It's perfectably serviceable, it functions and controls well, looks fairly decent for a DS port, has interesting challenges and generally does everything it needs to satisfactorily.  If you're not looking for anything mind-blowing or deep then it's a pretty fun way to kill 20 hours or so.

However, it is incredibly straightforward.  There's none of the emotional depth we've come to associate with the FF series, the characters are droll to the point of non-existence, the plot a simple series of macguffin fetch quests.  The job system is superficially interesting, but obtuse and grind-heavy.  The world is twee and standard, filled with cut-and-paste towns devoid of charm or character.

Overall, if you're simply looking for a simple fun romp through JRPG tropes you could do a lot worse, but don't expect any more than that.  For more mature, deep or involving games, you should probably look elsewhere.

reviewText: As someone who has played nearly every Final Fantasy game, I can say clearly in my opinion this IOS port of FF3 is not worth the full price tag, and if you did decide to pick it up i would suggest waiting till it becomes on sale. My main reason for saying that is because of what i said in the first line, it is nearly an exact IOS port, and in my opinion is not worth the 16ish dollars they are charging for the game. Another huge issue i have with the game that i find very frustrating is the combat. This game uses the job system, and the set up for the job system is what makes it a deal breaker for me. For you're character to get points to level up their job, they have to take action in battle. If two of you're characters kill all the foes before you're other two members get a chance to attack, then only the two who fought get the job points for that battle. So if you happen to be using the mage classes, it will be very difficult to keep them up to pace with the other jobs because they will hardly ever get points. If you are loyal FF fan and you can get past the issues, then this game might we worth picking up if it was on sale. But i paid full price for the game, and can already tell that i 100% regret it.

Disappointment.

This is the word that sums up my experience with this game.

I'm a huge fan of the Final Fantasy games and never judge them on graphics alone.

What really upset me about this game is its 'simplicity'.

I think they had some amazing ideas and concepts in this game but I felt they didnt elaborate more on them.

For example.

reviewText:
Quick review:
+Fun battle system
+Fun development system
+Interesting world
+Good writing

-Story feels its age
-Development system lacks any major depth
-Convoluted magic system
-Difficulty curve is weird

*This review is based on the game Final Fantasy III, not just this particular port*

Final Fantasy III is a mixed bag that shows it age but still remains solid in gameplay, development and fun.

The story is standard fare, you play as an orphan collecting crystals and saving the world. Obviously there are more nuances there, but this is where the game truly feels its age with each character essentially being a blank canvas. The writing is interesting enough to offset the generic overtones though, it's generally something that Square are very good at. I want to emphasize that the story itself isn't bad though, you just shouldn't go in expecting something incredible.

(There's nothing wrong with this trope, seeing as Square was a large part of its popularity)

The gameplay is traditional turn based, using your agility stat to determine where you appear in a queue. Some abilities have higher priorities and will therefore be used first, if your agility equals someone elses.

The development system uses the Job system, and FFIII was the first Final Fantasy that let you freely change jobs outside of battle. You have jobs like White Mage (healer), Black Mage (nuker) and Knight (tank). There are lots of jobs to use, and you can make a party of your choosing. The development system is relatively shallow, but has enough depth to keep things interesting. This system was then perfected in Final Fantasy V. (steam release please)

The Magic system is a little bit iffy, instead of having a standard MP pool, you have a number of uses tacked on to each level of magic (which raises through levels) which means you could use nine level 1 spells and still use a level 2 spell after that, assuming you had charges for level 2 magic. You're also limited to only 3 slots per level of magic, meaning you have to make a decision on which magicks you want to use (especially if you use a red mage) I feel like they improved on this in subsequent titles. (MP pool, no choosing magicks)

The difficulty curve can make the game frustrating at points and too easy at other points, but it's never unfair or completely simple.

Visually the game looks OK. I've never personally been a fan of the DS esque chibi art though, so take that with a grain of salt. The game itself upscales pretty well, and looks nice on the PC unless you stare too intently and some of the textures.

The controls are ok, and very intuitive if you're using a controller and you've ever played another Final Fantasy game. The menus can be a bit sluggish sometimes, but it's never to the point of frustration. The zoom feature can be a pain sometimes too, but again it's never too bad.

Is this game worth the price tag? Yes and no. You will get £11($17)'s worth of content out of the game, but it does seem a little pricey seeing as this is a port of a port, and considering that you can buy FFVII and VIII for so cheap on steam currently. If you're a fan of the series or want a solid turn based RPG to keep you busy for a while, then I'd suggest picking it up. If you're unsure then I would wait until it comes on sale.

Oh and the music? The music is fantastic.

reviewText:
Short review. This is a plotless, characterless, timewasting grind.

Long Review.
Lets start with the basics. I used to play the old final fantasy games on the SNES, which were great and even now worth playing on an emulator. I saw this on sale, saw the job class system and was reminded of one of my favourite FF games with the same idea. I thought i'd enjoy this game even more with the enhanced graphics and suchlike. Wrong.

The job classes
I'm about a quarter of the way through the game and i'm about level 25 out of level 99 on my first job for each character. It is only because of reading the wiki page I find out that there is no significant benefit at all to mastering a class.
In the prior version, sticking with a class and mastering it was a good idea. If one of your characters mastered being a white mage, then you could select white magic as a secondary ability when you started a new class. This allowed for interesting and varied job combinations. This new version makes you start from scratch every time you start a new job. There are even better versions of the starting jobs which you will have to grind through again to make them any good since they will draw no benefit from having ground from the basic class. Utter time wasting and demoralising.

The characters
Weak and shallow. A few lines of dialogue to establish the basic idea and then thats it. You might get one line here and there to create the illusion that the characters have any depth, but really? I've not met one person in the game which with a worthwhile personality. Even the villains which should be the driving force of a game are non-exisitant. Once you've ground through a dungeon you get to meet someone with two lines of dialogue before you kill them. Yawn. This is just endless grinding, over and over.

The plot
Wait? There's a plot? Really? A few lines from some crystal to tell you that you're the chosen one and then you're off. Um... is that it? You bet it is. Save the world? Uh... it looks fine to me. No maurading armies, no cataclysmic natural disasters, no iconic villians with master plans. Just a vague reference to darkness being imbalanced. It's like a stoned aromatherapist ate some alphabet soup and ♥♥♥♥ out a story.

Overall
If you like endless grinding and having to start characters over again and again, not having to worry about plots, characters or indeed anything being memorable about the game, then this is the one for you.
I'm going to be uninstalling this and finding a SNES emulator to play some decent final fantasy.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy III is an unrewarding grind with a so-simple-it's-convoluted story reminiscent of Kingdom Hearts'.  The story is about the balance between light and darkness--and the game lectures and reminds the player about this balance a few hundred times throughout, as New Age-plagued JRPGs often do.

Its gameplay is where it fails on virtually every level: Most of the jobs are useless, half the abilities in the game are bugged and simply don't work, and players will lose hours upon hours of progress due to a complete absence of in-dungeon save points.  You can only save on the world map, and some dungeons are 5+ hours long.

Even players who only desire a peek at the advent of Final Fantasy's Job System will be disappointed, as the game's combat shoehorns players into a select few jobs, rendering the remainder not only unusable, but boring and uninspired as well.  For example, over half of the game's jobs are mere upgrades to existing jobs, offering nothing of substance on a gameplay level.

The music and graphics are sometimes surprisingly good.

I recommend this game to hardcore completionists and to Final Fantasy XIV fans who want to see the origins of the Crystal Tower" raid.  To anyone else: don't waste your time.  Final Fantasy III is just not good enough to justify the time investment."

The menu lay-out is spot on the mobile version (which I played on my Androids, GS2 and GS4) and the controls NEED to be changed to make sense.  Otherwise, I'm keeping my eye out for the numerous reported launch glitches.

Overall, I do not recommend this game.  Final Fantasy 3 is possibly the hardest in the franchise and compared to later games, it's a bit weird.  The characters (who didn't exist in the original NES version) are all card-board cut outs, and they don't even have basic architypes applied to them, so they're uninteresting, and the game's overall plot--while unique--is predictable and cliched (cliched due to setting the bar, not jumping on existing cliches).  Combat is basic, and character leveling and skill management is difficult to understand and never feels like it's making an impact, so grinding levels and items is always a chore in FFIII, plus you're in constant fear that a character may faint and you'll have to rush to a town with a revive fountain because Phoenix Downs are scarce.

If you are a fan of JRPGs or Old School RPGs, then I can't recommend playing this game overall, and this should be the best version of this classic, but I strongly feel most gamers will get upset or frustrated with this title.  I loved the Nintendo DS version, but I've played every game in the series (at least the main series) and understand that this one is black-sheep-ish compared to the styles and gameplay of the later games.

This game totally isn't worth $16 by the way.  The genre and indsutry changing classic, Final Fantasy VII is only $12, but that even seems too high for 3, considering it brings nothing new to the table.  It's just the iPhone/Android version, which was a single-screen DS version.  There's no update to the aesthetics and no content that improves the game, and 2006 DS graphics do not look good on a PC monitor made in the last ten years.

tldr, JRPG fans will like it, but it is a more advanced JRPG, so general gamers won't get into it.

reviewText: This game is a slightly modified and upscaled port of the DS remake (which was also ported to iOS and Android) of the Famicom original, originally released in 1990. While it is a great game overall, it does have its flaws. The game requires a lot of grinding, so if you aren't a fan of that, you won't like it in this. Unlike every game since IV (and the remakes of I and II), each level of magic has it's own MP level, and each one gains new MP individually. This means that when you get spells of a new magic level, you can only use them once or twice before healing, but you can get more MP with levels. However, the game has its good features. It was the first game to feature the Job system, which returned in later games like V and XIV: ARR. With this, you can change your characters classes freely, at any time. Overall, this is a great game, and I would recommend it.

reviewText: I've always been drawn to turn-based RPGs, so when Final Fantasy III was released on Steam, I decided I would buy it. Unlike most of the other Final Fantasies, this one utilizes a standard turn format, where the player and the enemy select commands and perform them in a single-file order until one side drops dead, as opposed to the active battle systems used in later games. The combat itself is well done, although the game makes no attempt to explain anything about itself to the player, making a bit of a sharp learning curve. The Magic system is a bit unorthodox, but after the player understands it, it becomes simple to function. Magic is equipped to each character individually, and is organized into 8 levels, each level having it's own MP. Each casting of a spell consumes one MP of that level. This makes magic rather ineffectual, because there is no way to recover MP aside from sleeping at an inn, healing at a spring, or using the rare Elixer item. It works well for what it is, but the player is discouraged from using magic, because it only has so many usages, making stronger magic less useful because it can only be cast once or twice. The game's defining feature, however, is its Job system. At predefined points in the game, the player will unlock Jobs that they can freely change their characters in and out of at any time outside of combat. Jobs level up just as characters do, and are the primary determinant of stats, which are wholly dependant on Job and Job Level, with the exception of HP, which is constant through all Jobs, although its growth is determined by the current Job. The Jobs work well, and playing with each one is entertaining, seeing all the ways Jobs can work together. However, they are very poorly balanced, with some Jobs, such as the Scholar or Evoker, being situationally useful at best, or utterly useless at worst. Thus, the player will tend to gravitate towards the same jobs every playthrough, ultimately hindering replay value. The game's replay value is prevalent, however, as thankfully, most jobs have at least some sort of niche to fill, preventing most jobs from falling into complete obscurity. The music, while there are some good tracks, is generally unnoteworthy, and the visuals aren't very appealing, as this game is a port of the DS version. The game also has a very ridiculous difficulty curve, with the game suddenly jumping from enemies dealing around 50 damage, to enemies dealing 150 damage, with absolutely no warning or gradual increase. To someone who knows the game well enough, the game is not very difficult, but to someone who does not know better, the game's difficulty will spike, particularly halfway through the game, where enemies will virtually instantly wipe you out if they get a Back Attack, and one particularly notable boss halfway into the game who will almost certainly crush your party. The game has severe balancing issues, but if you can get past that, it's a very well-made game that should occupy you for some time. What it does, it does well, and what it fails at are not too big of a detraction. I give this game my recommendation, so long as steep difficulty curves and turn-based combat are not a big detraction to you. This game will do nothing to change your stance if you don't appreciate the genre, but for those who do, it's an excellent foray.

reviewText:
I never played DS or mobile versions, so I can not compare, but I spent some time in port of original version for PSX. PC version of the Final Fantasy III is certainly fun, and updated visuals and interface brings a lot to the game. As with all the old FF games, there is not much story to speak of, the game is all about dungeon crawling and although you have some dialog here or there, most of them are simple and do not distract from action. I would actually sometimes appreciate more dialog in game, because it is easy to get lost in game sometimes due to lack of pointers about where to go next. You also have only four characters for whole game and all of them are active whole game if present (and alive), so you do not need to worry about managing and leveling up too many of them at the same time, which is common in some later games in the series.

Combat is turn based, but you are not restricted by time during turns, which makes it more strategic than more recent games. From modern FF games it is most similar to FF 10, although with less options when comes to spells, items or other actions. Final Fantasy III also uses job system. It means you can change character classes between fights, and there is more than 20 of them. Downside of it is that there is separate level system for character and jobs and no experience points and levels earned in one job transfers to another. Therefore you need to train every job separately and some dungeons require you to use specific jobs, which unfortunately makes some of them essential and other practically useless. And yes, the game does have random battles so depending on your preferences you will probably either love this style or hate it.

Bugs in PC port of the game is something which is spelled pretty often in other reviews here. As for my own experience, I knew about the biggest of them from the start and did not encounter any other mentioned here, my playthrough was pretty smooth. So I would recommend to save often to several files be sure (you have 3 maximum), never to return to your first town and use the restoration fountains after you break the rock which seals you in the first area, and you should be fine. Of course, the graphic is old for today's standard and locked in 15 fps in battles, true. But you are not exactly playing game from 2016 here and the the game looks nice as the chosen design fits its style.

In the whole, Final Fantasy III is certainly worth playing for all FF fans. LIke me, you may easily find that you will enjoy it more than some more recent installments in the series. Only given the price and age of the game, it may be better to wait for some steam sale.

+ Great example of old time jrpg
+ Updated visuals and interface
+ Turn-based combat system
+ Level design, monsters and bosses
-  Unbalanced job system
-  Does not tell you where to go next sometimes
-  PC version have at least one bug which can break game, although it can be avoided
-  Battles locked to 15 fps (depends on player if it matters)

reviewText:
If you are a die-hard Final Fantasy Fan who goes out of their way to play every game from 3-10 on Steam (1 &2 not yet released for PC) then Final Fantasy III is a must. First and foremost, this is a tough game to dedicate your time to beat. Currently I have held 52 hrs on record to play this game from start to finish. While the linear gameplay isn't necessarily that long, however it does take preparation to level up for the final challenge which is why it took me extra time plus completing much of the Steam achievement list.
As for the game itself, this version of Final Fantasy III is a remake of the original Nintendo DS handheld first released in the US in 2006. The original game came out in 1990 for the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) in Japan only. The 3d remake retains much of the
difficulty and control schemes of the original version typical of any RPG genre type game. The story is pretty clichéd and bland compared to the later Final Fantasy titles, but it still doesn't fail to entertain as it is filled with many surprises, plot twists, and some humorous moments. Furthermore as a trivia fact, III was the first game that introduced many of the series highlights, including the job class system, summons including Ramuh, Ifrit, Shiva, and Odin to name a few, the hit point system that popped up when striking an enemy, riding chocobos throughout the world map, the first appearance of the moogles and the boss battle theme made its debut in this game as well.
The gameplay elements involve character job classes ranging from a knight to magic user, summoner, thief or job class with special abilities. Many more job classes are picked up along the way as the game progresses. Completing the game depends on the player constantly adjusting and upgrading on these job classes (it takes time & effort on this). Experience points that are used to level up on your characters and job classes are gained by defeating monsters randomly encountered on the World Map field or dungeon level, (encounters can get repetitive and annoying this way) as they are not seen.
This version does not include special features like a music track, or art gallery by Final Fantasy series artist Yoshitaka Amano, but does include a bestiary (viewable list of monsters defeated) which counts towards completing a Steam achievement. However, the bestiary is not viewed from the game's main menu, but rather much later in the game after achieving  a certain vehicle.
Overall, this has been one of the best classical Final Fantasy titles to play, but players be prepared for its classical difficulty and extended time to completing it.
